messages: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:33): http://www.w3.org/html/logo/ ?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:33): via 58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (13:34): Is the W3C now officially going widen the definition of "HTML5" to "any (partially) avaialble web technology in 2011"?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:35): it's not like embrace and extend has not worked before
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:36): I guess it is better to do it yourself than let someone else do it to you
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (13:36): Fair point
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:36): What's the deal with the military rank symbol for semantics?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:37): The styling symbol looks like military insignia, too.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:38): Sarge Semantics?
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (13:38): "If, as W3C hopes, the community embraces the logo, W3C will adopt it as its own official logo for HTML5 in the first quarter of 2011."
abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (13:39): Great. Now the W3C are encouraging people to think of CSS3 as being part of HTML5. I give up.
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (13:39): Exactly my thought, telling people it's not true will be a lost cause if this catches on
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:42): Will be interesting to see what the Wikipedia consensus is going to be. Or maybe the flamewars will be more interesting.
abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (13:42): I feel a blog post coming on.
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (13:43): feels a sudden urge to do some trolling
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (13:43): standards nerd catnip
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:43): I encourage laughing instead :)

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:54): it's not that bad. They are providing separate logos to represent separate feature sets, and the way the logo builder works just seems to illustrate that the technologies all work together.

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:55): also, the use of "HTML5" as the umbrella term to cover everything is already widespread. That's not a problem that can be solved without a replacement term, and many have been tried and eventually failed over the years
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:56): We already gave up on HTML5 some time ago for things other than marketing. It's called HTML these days.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (13:57): Can't the HTML5 Super friends adopt the logo, getting spandex suits in the process?
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (14:09): is discovering http://www.w3.org/html/logo/
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (14:09): I mean in the logs here
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:09): it's also plastered all over twitter by now

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:10): it's like the Internet and SMS had a baby
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (14:11): hehe :) 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 this one is the private one. :) the public one is http://twitter.com/karlpro

1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (14:15): but if you meant private in the sense not viewable by twitter dragons‚Ä¶ I define my level of opacity
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (14:15): sees http://www.w3.org/QA/2011/01/an_html5_logo
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:17): already made an html5 logo years ago http://simon.html5.org/valid-html5.png
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:17): wonders who chose "zeldman orange" for the logo
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (14:18): Michael Nieling
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:18): So it's him that I will offend by not liking it? (Not just the orange)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:19): wait, the logo is for selling t-shirts to fund the html5 testsuite?
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (14:20): As in, everyone who submits a test gets a beer?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:20): doesn't like that plan
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (14:21): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: too many tests? You fear for your liver?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:21): "We are also selling T-shirts and part of the proceeds will support the HTML5 test suite effort." http://www.w3.org/QA/2011/01/an_html5_logo
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:22): wonder why they didn't make the logo say "5 > 2"
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (14:23): The term "W3C" actually is a trending topic on Twitter now
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (14:23): (Or an equivalent non-alcoholic beverage)
9dfea2f9bd9114520591dceb20d528a1 (14:24): That's a terrible logo
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:24): Hmm. What non-alcoholic beverage is equivalent to beer?
9dfea2f9bd9114520591dceb20d528a1 (14:24): non-alcoholic beer?
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (14:24): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: That would be budweiser
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:25): I still don't like this plan
9dfea2f9bd9114520591dceb20d528a1 (14:26): "This Google App Engine application is temporarily over its serving quota. Please try again later. "
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:27): I'll take b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea's beer
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:28): This is not getting better :p
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:34): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: your font subsetter tells me: Too late for "-CA" option at subset.pl line 1.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:34): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: what should I do?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:36): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: it runs if I zap -CA...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:40): where does HTML5 define what happens with displaying <table><form><tr><td>x ?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:40): especially the <form>
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:40): it becomes an empty child of <table> per the parser
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:41): it ought to be display:none somehow, right?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:42): in the rendering section
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:43): ooh
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:43): irrespective of CSS rules
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (14:43): Gecko removed its table>form rule recently, IIRC
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:44): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Run it like "perl -CA subsetter.pl" or "./subsetter.pl", I think
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:44): (not like "perl subsetter.pl")
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:44): so even if I do form { display:block; outline:4em solid purple } nothing should show up?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:44): okay...
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:44): (The -CA option is to make it parse command-line arguments as UTF-8, I think)
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (14:46): I didn't recall correctly, apparently
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:49): thanks for the help btw

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:50): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: any idea why browsers are OK with fonts that I subset from .ttf original but are unhappy with loading subsets made by subsetting a .ttf converted from .otf using fontforge
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:51): What kind of unhappy?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:51): (I changed em box from 1000 to 1024, added points at extrema and rounded to integer coordinates)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:51): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Firefox and Chrome don't load the font

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:53): Hmm, I think Fontforge OTF->TTF conversion has worked for me in the past (without bothering to fix any of those warnings about em boxes or whatever), except for being ugly
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:53): Can you load the un-subsetted TTF-from-OTF in those browsers?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:58): Sounds somewhat like a subsetter bug, then :-(

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:01): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: font file is http://webm.html5.org/fonts/BaskervaldADFStd-Heavy.ttf and http://webm.html5.org/fonts/heading-characters.txt is the character file
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:02): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: http://webm.html5.org/fonts/Baskervald.ttf is the output that doesn't work

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:04): An exception occurred during the decompilation of the 'OS/2' table
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:04): which doesn't sound good
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:16): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: https://bitbucket.org/philip/font-optimizer/changeset/3ec118f146c7

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:17): (I assume I never hit that problem myself because I was using older versions of Fontforge which didn't use the new table version)
